caption: Comparisons of 4D Scene Reconstruction. We report the mIoU scores of OccSora (Wang et al., 2024) and our DynamicCity framework on the CarlaSC, Occ3D-Waymo, and Occ3D-nuScenes datasets, respectively, under different resolutions and sequence lengths. Symbol † denotes score reported in the OccSora paper. Other scores are reproduced using the official code.
description: This table compares the performance of the proposed DynamicCity model against OccSora on 4D scene reconstruction across three different datasets: CarlaSC, Occ3D-Waymo, and Occ3D-nuScenes.  For each dataset, the table shows the mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) scores achieved by both methods under varying conditions of scene resolution (128x128x8 or 200x200x16 pixels), and sequence length (4, 8, 16, or 32 frames). The improvement achieved by DynamicCity over OccSora is also indicated in parentheses for each configuration. Note that some OccSora scores marked with † are from the original paper, while others were reproduced using the official code.

caption: Comparisons of 4D Scene Generation. We report the Inception Score (IS), Fréchet Inception Distance (FID), Kernel Inception Distance (KID), and the Precision (P) and Recall (R) rates of SemCity (Lee et al., 2024), OccSora (Wang et al., 2024), and our DynamicCity framework on the CarlaSC and Occ3D-Waymo datasets, respectively, in both the 2D and 3D spaces.
description: This table compares the performance of three different methods (SemCity, OccSora, and DynamicCity) for 4D scene generation on two datasets (CarlaSC and Occ3D-Waymo).  The comparison is done using several metrics in both 2D and 3D spaces: Inception Score (IS), Fréchet Inception Distance (FID), Kernel Inception Distance (KID), Precision (P), and Recall (R).  The number of frames used for each method is also included. Higher IS scores and lower FID and KID scores indicate better performance. Higher precision and recall also suggest a better model.

caption: Table 3: Ablation Study on VAE Network Structures. We report the mIoU scores, training time (second-per-iteration), and training-time memory consumption (VRAM) of different Encoder and Decoder configurations on CarlaSC and Occ3D-Waymo, respectively. Note that "ESS" denotes "Expansion & Squeeze". The best and second-best values are in bold and underlined.
description: This ablation study table assesses the performance of various VAE network structures. It compares different encoder and decoder configurations, specifically focusing on the impact of using average pooling versus a projection module, and whether the expansion and squeeze strategy (ESS) is employed.  The table reports the mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) scores, training time (seconds per iteration), and VRAM (memory usage in gigabytes) for each configuration on two datasets: CarlaSC and Occ3D-Waymo.  The best and second-best results for each metric and dataset are highlighted in bold and underlined, respectively, to easily identify the superior configurations.

caption: Table 3: Ablation Study on VAE Network Structures. We report the mIoU scores, training time (second-per-iteration), and training-time memory consumption (VRAM) of different Encoder and Decoder configurations on CarlaSC and Occ3D-Waymo, respectively. Note that "ESS" denotes "Expansion & Squeeze". The best and second-best values are in bold and underlined.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on the VAE network structures used in DynamicCity. It compares the mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) scores, training time per iteration (in seconds), and the amount of video RAM (VRAM) consumed during training for different configurations of the encoder and decoder networks. The configurations vary in terms of the pooling method used (average pooling or projection), and whether the Expansion & Squeeze Strategy (ESS) is employed. Results are shown separately for the CarlaSC and Occ3D-Waymo datasets. The best and second-best results for each metric are highlighted in bold and underlined, respectively. The table helps quantify the impact of different design choices in the VAE model on its performance and resource utilization.

caption: Table 1: Comparisons of 4D Scene Reconstruction. We report the mIoU scores of OccSora (Wang et al., 2024) and our DynamicCity framework on the CarlaSC, Occ3D-Waymo, and Occ3D-nuScenes datasets, respectively, under different resolutions and sequence lengths. Symbol † denotes score reported in the OccSora paper. Other scores are reproduced using the official code.
description: This table compares the performance of the DynamicCity model and the OccSora model on 4D scene reconstruction across three different datasets: CarlaSC, Occ3D-Waymo, and Occ3D-nuScenes.  For each dataset, the table shows the number of classes, the resolution of the scene (height x width x depth in meters), the number of frames in the sequence, and the mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) scores achieved by both DynamicCity and OccSora.  The mIoU score reflects the accuracy of the models in reconstructing the 4D LiDAR scenes.  Parentheses following the DynamicCity mIoU scores show the percentage improvement over OccSora.
